weighting and calibration.selection_criteria: Top authors by document count using weighting and calibration
weighting and calibration.data_source: Author-method mapping from RAND metadata + LLM methodology extraction

sample_processes.sample_description: 18 CISOs were interviewed, with a non-random sample drawn from various sectors (military, communications, government, finance, manufacturing). The heuristic model simulates over 100 types of organizations.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data was used to inform the development of a quantitative heuristic model.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the impact of varying key parameters on model outcomes.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study included three school districts and four charter management organizations.  Interviews were conducted with central office staff, school leaders, and teachers. Surveys were administered to all school leaders and a stratified random sample of teachers.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis of interviews using NVivo 10, thematic coding, and inductive coding. Quantitative analysis of survey data using Stata, including sampling weights and nonresponse adjustments.  Implementation status coded using a point system and converted to percentages. Nonresponse analysis conducted using two-level hierarchical generalized linear models.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study focused on one school district in Tulsa, Oklahoma, with a target enrollment of 880 students in grades 6-9 during the 2014-2015 school year.  The sample is not representative and limits generalizability.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The total costs were calculated by summing across individual resource ingredients.  Personnel costs were aggregated to protect employee salary information.  Natural units (e.g., FTEs) were used to value resources in a way that is less sensitive to local cost variations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: A representative PuP database of over 250 installation PuPs was created, selected to represent the diversity of existing partnerships across all Services, functional areas, and partnership types.  In-depth case studies included at least one interview with an installation or community member directly involved in the partnership.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The PuP database was analyzed to understand the range of partnership types, approaches, benefits, and other key aspects.  The case studies examined partnership development and implementation, including benefits and barriers and how they were addressed.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The ashore force used in the analysis was a Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU) of approximately 3,000 Marines.  The study assumed 10% of the force (300) were contaminated, including 24 litter casualties and 75 ambulatory casualties.  This scenario also included 100 service members with conventional injuries.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The assessment of current Navy capability was structured around four amphibious mission functions: transporting forces, receiving casualties, decontaminating forces, and returning ships to full mission capability.  Data from various sources were used to evaluate existing capabilities and identify potential improvements.  Spreadsheet models were used to calculate transport times and throughput rates.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

interviews.data_source: Gemini Flash LLM extraction from full RAND document text
interviews.methodology_extraction_basis: Full document analysis with section identification

sample_processes.sample_description: 18 CISOs were interviewed, with a non-random sample drawn from various sectors (military, communications, government, finance, manufacturing). The heuristic model simulates over 100 types of organizations.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data was used to inform the development of a quantitative heuristic model.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the impact of varying key parameters on model outcomes.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The survey included all task team leaders (TTLs) and principal investigators (PIs) named on applications to the first three SIEF calls for funding.  The online focus group included 10 DFID staff. In-depth interviews were conducted with SIEF staff, NGOs, peers (e.g., 3ie, DIME), and donors (CIFF).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Data from different methods were synthesized to answer six core research questions and several secondary research questions.  Analysis included comparing SIEF costs with those of peer funders, examining survey response rates and disaggregating data by respondent characteristics (position, cluster, call for proposal), and assessing workshop data through pre- and post-tests and overall assessments. Qualitative data from interviews and focus groups were also analyzed.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) covering fiscal years 2004-2012 on military-to-civilian conversions.  The analysis focused primarily on conversions filled by federal civilian employees.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Analysis of DMDC data to understand patterns in conversions, including substitution ratios, variations across services, and occupational trends.  Qualitative analysis of expert interviews to identify impediments to authorizing and executing conversions.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The scoping workshop included 16 staff from the Digital Catapult's senior leadership team and those with challenge area responsibilities. Follow-up communications were conducted with the CEO, Commercial Officer, Marketing Director, and Senior Manager of Creative Programmes.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The evidence was analyzed and synthesized within a productivity conceptual framework to contextualize the Digital Catapult's activities and their potential contribution to productivity gains.  A 'theory of change' approach was used to understand the causal links between the Catapult's activities and productivity outcomes.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Eight case studies of counterterrorism technology applications in Europe and the US were analyzed.  27 semi-structured interviews were conducted with academics, policymakers, law enforcement practitioners, and human rights experts from various European countries and the US. Five European Court of Human Rights cases were analyzed.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of case studies and interview data; thematic analysis to identify key themes and policy implications; review and synthesis of findings from previous TACTICS deliverables and relevant case law.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

document review.data_source: Gemini Flash LLM extraction from full RAND document text
document review.methodology_extraction_basis: Full document analysis with section identification

sample_processes.sample_description: 18 CISOs were interviewed, with a non-random sample drawn from various sectors (military, communications, government, finance, manufacturing). The heuristic model simulates over 100 types of organizations.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data was used to inform the development of a quantitative heuristic model.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the impact of varying key parameters on model outcomes.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Adults (18+) with a diagnosis of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), including those with comorbidities.  Studies included various SJW extracts and dosages, with comparators including placebo and various antidepressants.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Random-effects meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for efficacy and number of adverse events.  Exact conditional methods used for specific adverse events.  GRADE approach used for quality of evidence assessment.  Subgroup analyses explored monotherapy vs. adjunctive therapy, different extracts, and depression severity.  Sensitivity analyses tested robustness of results.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The analysis focuses on the state of Pennsylvania and its budget.  Specific data points are drawn from various sources, including the Commonwealth's budget and the Independent Fiscal Office.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis uses the COMPARE model to estimate costs and revenues under different assumptions.  Sensitivity analysis is performed by varying key assumptions (administrative costs, GRT applicability, CHIP to Medicaid transition costs, economic growth tax revenue, and General Assistance savings) to assess the robustness of the findings.  Results are presented in a table showing the budgetary impact under various scenarios.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Over 94,700 flights completed by C-5, C-17, and C-130 aircraft during FY 2012.  Data cleaned to exclude training flights and those requiring air refueling.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis compares fuel costs of historical flights with and without tankering, considering various factors (fuel prices, burn penalty, capacity, etc.). Simulations are used to model different scenarios (wartime/peacetime, information sharing, fuel offloading) and assess the impact on cost savings from both AMC and DoD perspectives.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study sample includes completed SRIAs submitted to the California Department of Finance between 2014 and 2022.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis approach involves a review of existing SRIAs, relevant literature, and government guidance to identify best practices and common issues in conducting SRIAs in California.  The analysis also compares different macroeconomic models used in these assessments.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sensitivity analysis.data_source: Gemini Flash LLM extraction from full RAND document text
sensitivity analysis.methodology_extraction_basis: Full document analysis with section identification

sample_processes.sample_description: The study primarily focuses on research conducted with adult populations in the United States, with some inclusion of research on children and adults in other Western nations.  The study prioritizes literature reviews, meta-analyses, and ongoing bodies of research over smaller-scale studies.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study analyzes existing research on the relationship between behavioral fitness constructs (sleep, alcohol and drug use, tobacco use) and resilience, well-being, and stress.  The analysis focuses on identifying key constructs, measures, and interventions, and evaluating the effectiveness of different interventions based on the available evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Three case studies: Newport News Shipbuilding (USA), Austal USA (USA), and Saab Aeronautics' Gripen program (Sweden).  Additional interviews and literature reviews were conducted on other shipbuilders (Bath Iron Works, Ingalls Shipbuilding, Marinette Marine Corporation), but these were not as in-depth.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of case studies, supplemented by quantitative data where available (e.g., employment figures, revenue data).  Critical review and interpretation of existing economic multiplier studies and their limitations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The literature review primarily focused on research from the past decade, conducted in the United States, on adult populations.  Studies on children were included when relevant, and some research from other Western nations was also considered.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved a systematic review and synthesis of existing research on physical fitness, physical activity, and interventions to promote them.  The findings were categorized and discussed in relation to the Total Force Fitness framework and the concept of resilience.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study does not involve a new data collection effort.  Instead, it analyzes existing research on nutritional fitness, focusing primarily on studies conducted in the United States and involving adult populations.  Some studies on children and other Western nations are included where relevant.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach is a systematic review and qualitative synthesis of existing research findings on nutritional fitness constructs, measures, and interventions.  The authors identify and summarize key findings from various studies, highlighting methodological strengths and weaknesses.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 60 interviewees (doctors, patient representatives, and others) from six European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the UK).  The sample is not representative of the entire population of these countries.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: PESTLE analysis was used to analyze findings from the literature review and interviews.  Future scenarios were developed and refined through a workshop with a steering committee. The analysis focused on identifying challenges and developing recommendations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

literature review.data_source: Gemini Flash LLM extraction from full RAND document text
literature review.methodology_extraction_basis: Full document analysis with section identification

The study prioritizes literature reviews, meta-analyses, and ongoing bodies of research over smaller-scale studies.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study analyzes existing research on the relationship between behavioral fitness constructs (sleep, alcohol and drug use, tobacco use) and resilience, well-being, and stress.  The analysis focuses on identifying key constructs, measures, and interventions, and evaluating the effectiveness of different interventions based on the available evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Adults (≥18 years) diagnosed with MDD according to DSM or ICD criteria.  Studies of populations with a history of MDD included if data on depressive symptoms or relapse were reported.  Specific inclusion and exclusion criteria detailed in the Methods section.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Standardized mean differences (SMDs) and relative risks (RRs) calculated. Meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random-effects models.  Publication bias investigated using Begg's and Egger's tests. Subgroup analyses and meta-regression used to explore effect modifiers. GRADE approach used to assess quality of evidence.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The sample consisted of studies identified through database searches and snowball sampling, meeting pre-defined inclusion and exclusion criteria.  The studies varied in methodology and quality, with only a small number considered methodologically robust.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Studies were assessed for quality using the Maryland Scientific Methods Scale.  Findings were synthesized and interpreted across studies.  Quantitative analyses within individual studies varied, including regression models and pre/post comparisons.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study examined nearly 4,900 SUAS, initially filtering out systems from China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea.  Further filtering was applied based on use case parameters (Table 2). The final analysis focused on 176 SUAS that met or nearly met the key features of the use cases.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved comparing SUAS against six use cases (Table 1) based on key features and specifications (Table 2).  SUAS were categorized based on their potential for near-term acquisition (Table 4) and whether they met or nearly met the key features of each use case.  The results are presented in tables summarizing the number of SUAS meeting various criteria (Tables 5, A.1-A.7).
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of active-duty members of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force (up to pay grade O-6), at least 18 years old at the start of the survey period.  Included both those currently serving overseas and those who had served overseas previously.  Sample size of 11,306 for questions related to tour extension.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, multivariate statistical modeling (probit and interval regression), cluster analysis to group attitudinal data.  Marginal effects were calculated to interpret the results of the statistical models.  Steady-state analysis was used to estimate long-run costs and savings of tour extensions.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 1,272 California K–12 public school principals (14% response rate).  Respondent schools were demographically similar to all California schools in terms of school type (elementary vs. secondary) and percentage of students receiving free or reduced-priced lunches.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Comparisons were made among responses of elementary, middle, and high school principals.  The report focuses on the severity of reported problems and the implementation of PEI activities, including comparisons across school levels and between schools reporting moderate or severe problems versus those not reporting such problems.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The survey included all task team leaders (TTLs) and principal investigators (PIs) named on applications to the first three SIEF calls for funding.  The online focus group included 10 DFID staff. In-depth interviews were conducted with SIEF staff, NGOs, peers (e.g., 3ie, DIME), and donors (CIFF).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Data from different methods were synthesized to answer six core research questions and several secondary research questions.  Analysis included comparing SIEF costs with those of peer funders, examining survey response rates and disaggregating data by respondent characteristics (position, cluster, call for proposal), and assessing workshop data through pre- and post-tests and overall assessments. Qualitative data from interviews and focus groups were also analyzed.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The sample included representatives from all EU Member States, European institutions, EU agencies, EU-funded projects, international organizations, third countries, civil society, and the chemical industry.  The EEAS survey included responses from 16 delegations. The public consultation received 121 contributions.  The sample for the expert consultation consisted of 3 experts.  Limitations regarding representativeness of the public consultation are noted.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A traffic light system (green, amber, red) was used to assess Action Plan implementation. Data from various sources were triangulated and synthesized using an evaluation framework (Annex H) to answer the 13 evaluation questions. Limitations regarding data availability and the attribution of observed trends are acknowledged.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study focused on a convenience sample of students in a single New York City high school.  The sample included two classrooms of 39 high school seniors in the web design subtrack who took the Startup Tech course.  Comparison students were drawn from the same school, considering students in grades 10-12.  Due to limitations, two model specifications were used: one including students across grades 10-12 with controls for grade and subtrack fixed effects, and another limited to 12th-grade students with controls for admissions track fixed effects.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Two main analytical approaches were employed: 1) Cross-sectional analysis comparing spring 2016 survey responses of Startup Tech students with those of comparison students, adjusting for observable differences using doubly robust estimation and propensity score weighting.  Two model specifications were used here, one with subtrack controls and one with admissions track controls. 2) Difference-in-differences analysis examining changes in individual student survey responses between two survey waves (January and April 2016), comparing changes among Startup Tech students to changes among non-participants.  Again, two model specifications were used, one with subtrack and grade-level controls and one with admissions track controls.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

Included both those currently serving overseas and those who had served overseas previously.  Sample size of 11,306 for questions related to tour extension.

Marginal effects were calculated to interpret the results of the statistical models.  Steady-state analysis was used to estimate long-run costs and savings of tour extensions.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from New York City Department of Education (NYCDOE) schools.  Community schools are compared to a matched comparison group of similar schools that were not designated as community schools. Subgroup analyses are conducted for various student and school characteristics.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A difference-in-differences approach is used to estimate the impact of the NYC Community Schools Initiative (NYC-CS).  School-level average outcomes are used in the primary analysis.  Weighted least squares regression is employed, with standard errors clustered by school.  Subgroup analyses are conducted to examine heterogeneity in program impacts based on student and school characteristics.  A grade-by-year analysis decomposes changes in impact over time into maturity and exposure components.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

Additional interviews and literature reviews were conducted on other shipbuilders (Bath Iron Works, Ingalls Shipbuilding, Marinette Marine Corporation), but these were not as in-depth.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including the Defense Manpower Data Center, the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System (DEERS), and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI).  Specific samples include Air Force intelligence personnel, and broader samples of the intelligence community workforce across different agencies and personnel types (civilian, military, contractor).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involves quantitative analysis of workforce data (e.g., continuation rates, personnel profiles), qualitative analysis of policy documents and reports, and a comparative analysis of different workforce planning tools and methodologies.  The study also adapts existing models (e.g., the DoD base force concept) to the context of the intelligence community.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 20 focus countries were selected from 156 countries receiving U.S. military and police aid, considering factors such as Leahy process type (fast-track or traditional), amount of aid received, and geographic combatant command.  The sample aimed to represent various vetting processes, aid levels, and geographic regions. Over 75 officials from various DoS bureaus, U.S. embassies, CCMDs, and DoD agencies were interviewed.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of interview data (including coding of interview transcripts), quantitative analysis of aggregated INVEST data, and analysis of embassy SOPs to identify trends, best practices, and problem areas related to the six research questions.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Ten CONUS-based Ammunition Supply Points (ASPs) were selected for in-depth analysis, chosen to represent a range of sizes, types of units supported, geographic locations, and personnel assignments.  A case study was also conducted on the USMC's ammunition supply chain.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Quantitative comparisons of ASP attributes were made using the RAND ASP Benchmarking Tool and five key metrics. Qualitative data from surveys and interviews provided context for understanding these comparisons.  The findings were then used to develop recommendations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 13 programs in 10 states that received FY13 Beyond Yellow Ribbon (BYR) funding.  The programs were selected by the research sponsor.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of program write-ups.  Write-ups were coded to identify cross-cutting themes related to facilitators, challenges, promising practices, and areas for improvement.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Three case studies: Newport News Shipbuilding (USA), Austal USA (USA), and Saab Aeronautics' Gripen program (Sweden).  Additional interviews and literature reviews were conducted on other shipbuilders (Bath Iron Works, Ingalls Shipbuilding, Marinette Marine Corporation), but these were not as in-depth.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of case studies, supplemented by quantitative data where available (e.g., employment figures, revenue data).  Critical review and interpretation of existing economic multiplier studies and their limitations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC) covering fiscal years 2004-2012 on military-to-civilian conversions.  The analysis focused primarily on conversions filled by federal civilian employees.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Analysis of DMDC data to understand patterns in conversions, including substitution ratios, variations across services, and occupational trends.  Qualitative analysis of expert interviews to identify impediments to authorizing and executing conversions.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study does not have a specific sample in the traditional sense.  The analysis is based on existing Air Force data and policies, and the findings are generalized to the Air Force I&MS enterprise.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The primary analysis approach is qualitative and involves developing a conceptual framework, analyzing existing processes, and proposing a new measurement system.  Quantitative analysis is used to a lesser extent, primarily to illustrate the impacts of deployments on home-station operations using existing Air Force data and metrics.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Five interviews with subject-matter experts from DoD IO, functional, and commercial social media analysis communities.  Note that this is not a generalizable sample.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Synthesizing research findings from literature review and interviews.  Applying various social media analytic methods to address common IO challenges.  Combining multiple analytic methods for richer insights.  Using statistical tests to analyze word frequencies, word distance, and other textual characteristics.  Employing machine learning and deep neural networks for image classification and analysis.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study examined major Air Force ERP programs (AF-IPPS, DEAMS, ECSS) and included interviews with government stakeholders (functional sponsors, PMOs, FMOs, acquisition leadership, Service and OSD DCMO staff, and Service CIO staff) and contractor stakeholders (system integrators, software vendors, and ERP expert consultants).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The research team organized conditions for successful ERP-enabled business transformation into five categories: business case, governance, business process reengineering (BPR), organizational change management (OCM), and IT acquisition.  These categories were used as a framework for analyzing the planning issues and challenges faced by the Air Force.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study draws on polling data from more than 50 opinion surveys conducted over the past 80 years (1935-2014), supplemented by a RAND American Life Panel survey in 2014.  Specific sample sizes for each survey are mentioned throughout Chapter Four.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis of survey data within the context of USAF narratives, social currency, contemporary operations, and broader strategy discussions.  Quantitative data is used descriptively to illustrate trends, but formal statistical analysis is avoided due to data limitations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 60 interviewees (doctors, patient representatives, and others) from six European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the UK).  The sample is not representative of the entire population of these countries.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: PESTLE analysis was used to analyze findings from the literature review and interviews.  Future scenarios were developed and refined through a workshop with a steering committee. The analysis focused on identifying challenges and developing recommendations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses historical data from various periods in the National Guard's history, including the militia era, the volunteer period, the strategic reserve period, and the operational reserve period.  The analysis also incorporates relevant sociological literature on the concept of the 'citizen soldier'.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study employs a qualitative approach, analyzing historical records and sociological literature to assess the validity of three claims regarding the National Guard.  The analysis focuses on identifying observable implications of each claim and evaluating whether the historical record supports these implications.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 254 entries from Kongjun Bao (PLAAF's official newspaper) covering SAM training activities from November 1, 2013, to October 31, 2014. A secondary dataset of 88 entries from 2004-2006 was also used for comparison.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The data were categorized by type of training activity (basic training, drills, exercises) and by nine key training dimensions.  Geographic and temporal variations in training were analyzed.  The 2013-2014 data were compared with the 2004-2006 data to identify changes over time.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Approximately a dozen North Korean elite defectors from university, scientific, diplomatic, security, military, and merchant communities.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The author postulates conditions for elite acceptance of unification based on existing literature and regime statements. These presumptions are then tested and refined through interviews with North Korean elite defectors.  Case studies of NKPA generals and North Korean physicians illustrate the application of the findings.

sample_processes.sample_description: Adults (18+) with a diagnosis of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), including those with comorbidities.  Studies included various SJW extracts and dosages, with comparators including placebo and various antidepressants.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Random-effects meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for efficacy and number of adverse events.  Exact conditional methods used for specific adverse events.  GRADE approach used for quality of evidence assessment.  Subgroup analyses explored monotherapy vs. adjunctive therapy, different extracts, and depression severity.  Sensitivity analyses tested robustness of results.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Adults (≥18 years) diagnosed with MDD according to DSM or ICD criteria.  Studies of populations with a history of MDD included if data on depressive symptoms or relapse were reported.  Specific inclusion and exclusion criteria detailed in the Methods section.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Standardized mean differences (SMDs) and relative risks (RRs) calculated. Meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for random-effects models.  Publication bias investigated using Begg's and Egger's tests. Subgroup analyses and meta-regression used to explore effect modifiers. GRADE approach used to assess quality of evidence.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Adults (18 years or older) with PTSD, including both male and female participants with various trauma types (military, sexual assault, physical abuse, etc.). Comorbidities were allowed.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Random effects meta-analysis using the Hartung-Knapp-Sidik-Jonkman method for continuous and categorical outcomes. Subgroup analyses and meta-regressions were conducted to explore effect modifiers. Sensitivity analyses were performed to assess robustness. Publication bias was assessed using Begg and Egger tests, with trim and fill method applied if necessary.  GRADE approach used for quality of evidence assessment.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Nondisabled, childless adults aged 19-64 with family income below 100% of the FPL, excluding states with pre-existing Medicaid eligibility for this group.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Regression-adjusted differences-in-differences approach comparing changes in insurance coverage over time between Medicaid expansion and non-expansion states, controlling for demographic factors and nationwide changes.  Sensitivity analyses explored different assumptions about pre-existing trends and the inclusion of specific data years.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from New York City Department of Education (NYCDOE) schools.  Community schools are compared to a matched comparison group of similar schools that were not designated as community schools. Subgroup analyses are conducted for various student and school characteristics.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A difference-in-differences approach is used to estimate the impact of the NYC Community Schools Initiative (NYC-CS).  School-level average outcomes are used in the primary analysis.  Weighted least squares regression is employed, with standard errors clustered by school.  Subgroup analyses are conducted to examine heterogeneity in program impacts based on student and school characteristics.  A grade-by-year analysis decomposes changes in impact over time into maturity and exposure components.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data from IQVIA MIDAS for 2022, covering the United States and 33 other OECD countries.  Data were cleaned to exclude over-the-counter drugs, records with non-positive volume or sales, inconsistent data, and presentations with low volume or sales.  The final sample varied depending on the specific analysis.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Bilateral price index comparisons were conducted between the U.S. and each of the other 33 countries, as well as a comparison of U.S. prices with the average of all other countries.  U.S. volume weights were primarily used, with sensitivity analyses using other country weights and blended weights.  Subgroup analyses were performed for different drug categories, and sensitivity analyses explored the impact of various methodological choices (e.g., aggregation level, price ratio exclusion criteria).
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses a snapshot of the 2025 projected fighter force structure, including active-duty, reserve, and Air National Guard units.  Specific bases and ranges are identified in the analysis.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Effectiveness is assessed by the weighted number of fighter squadrons within 150 nautical miles of upgraded ranges. Costs are compared for range upgrades and squadron restationing. Risks are evaluated using hazard maps, climate projections, and power reliability data.  The analysis explores the interaction of range upgrade and squadron restationing policies under various constraints.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis using Dedoose software to identify recurring patterns in qualitative data. Iterative rounds of data analysis by a team of four coders to develop a hierarchical code tree.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study included data from publicly available information on Santa Monica demographics, parent survey data collected by the city and SMMUSD, five focus groups with Santa Monica parents, cost data from a small sample of ESAC providers, and interviews with a broad range of stakeholders including parents, representatives from organizations such as the local community college and the Parent-Teacher Association, and providers.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved constructing an inventory of local programs, analyzing parent survey data, and identifying best practice models from other communities.  The findings were organized around four key themes: access and participation, quality of care, service delivery, and financing.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study used data from the Household Travel Survey (HTS), specifically focusing on data from school days and comparing it to existing data representing workdays.  The sample size was reduced by approximately 20% when switching to the school day definition.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The core analysis involved comparing parameters and predictions from the re-estimated school-day models to those of the original workday models and to observed data from the HTS.  This included calculating differences in tour and detour rates and assessing the statistical significance of parameter changes.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from the Sydney Strategic Transport Model (STM), updated to reflect a 2011 base year.  Data sources include the expanded 2004–9 Household Travel Survey (HTS).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involves model estimation using various statistical techniques (multinomial logit), model validation through calculation of implied values of time and elasticities, and comparison of model predictions with observed data using RMS measures.  The models are implemented using segmentation to account for variations in travel behavior.

sample_processes.sample_description: Three large-scale research projects (arthritis, cardiovascular disease and stroke, mental health) with a total of 63 case studies of separate research projects, ideas, or programs. Case studies included a mix of low, mid, and high impact research, selected using various methods (citation analysis, PI surveys, etc.) depending on the study.  The research projects themselves were conducted 10-20 years prior to the analysis.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The impact of each research project was rated in five categories of the Payback Framework.  Researchers then analyzed what characteristics of the research, researchers, and research environment were associated with high impact in each category.  Findings were compared across the three studies, accounting for methodological differences.  The analysis involved both grouping of findings (e.g., academic vs. wider impact) and separate analysis by impact category.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from various sources, including the Defense Manpower Data Center, the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System (DEERS), and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI).  Specific samples include Air Force intelligence personnel, and broader samples of the intelligence community workforce across different agencies and personnel types (civilian, military, contractor).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involves quantitative analysis of workforce data (e.g., continuation rates, personnel profiles), qualitative analysis of policy documents and reports, and a comparative analysis of different workforce planning tools and methodologies.  The study also adapts existing models (e.g., the DoD base force concept) to the context of the intelligence community.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 62 public charter and district schools implementing personalized learning practices; a subset of 32 schools used for detailed implementation analysis; a matched comparison group of students from comparable schools.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of student achievement data (effect sizes, statistical significance); qualitative analysis of school design characteristics, teacher and administrator reports, and student perceptions; comparison of personalized learning schools to a national sample of schools.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from the Air Force Personnel Center (AFPC) on Air Force pilots and maintainers,  FAA data on pilot certifications, and publicly available data on airline employment and salaries.  Specific sample sizes are not always explicitly stated but are implied within the figures and tables presented.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis primarily involves descriptive statistics to characterize the Air Force and airline workforces.  Correlation analysis is used to assess the relationship between airline hiring and Air Force personnel losses.  Comparative analysis is used to compare Air Force and airline salaries and to assess the relative attractiveness of airline employment to Air Force personnel.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

comparative analysis.methodology_extraction_basis: Full document analysis with section identification

sample_processes.sample_description: Household Travel Survey (HTS) data from nine waves (1999/2000 to 2007/2008) were used.  Specific waves selected varied by travel purpose to balance sample size and representativeness for the 2006 base year. Sample sizes for toll road choices and train access mode choices were analyzed to ensure sufficient data for model extensions.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study used a tour-based approach to model home-based travel.  The model structure included nested logit and multinomial logit components to represent various choice decisions (mode, destination, access mode, station, toll road).  Model parameters were estimated using maximum likelihood estimation.  Model validation involved elasticity tests, value-of-time analysis, and comparison of observed and predicted tour length distributions.  Model specifications were refined iteratively based on model fit, elasticity values, and validation results.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The primary data source is the Household Travel Survey (HTS) data from New South Wales, spanning multiple years (1999-2008).  Specific samples were used for different models, often based on adult status groups and travel purposes.  Data exclusion criteria varied by model and included considerations such as weekday-only data, full-response households, and consistent data.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved re-estimating existing models with updated HTS data and refining model specifications through iterative testing and evaluation of parameter significance.  The approach involved comparing initial estimations using existing model structures with subsequent estimations incorporating new variables and adjustments to improve model fit and address issues such as negative acquisition rates or implausible parameter signs.  The final models were selected based on statistical significance and the plausibility of the estimated parameters.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Household Travel Survey (HTS) data from nine waves (1999/2000 to 2007/2008) were used.  Specific waves selected varied by travel purpose to balance sample size and representativeness for the 2006 base year. Sample sizes for toll road choices and train access mode choices were analyzed to ensure sufficient data for model extensions.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study used a tour-based approach to model home-based travel.  The model structure included nested logit and multinomial logit components to represent various choice decisions (mode, destination, access mode, station, toll road).  Model parameters were estimated using maximum likelihood estimation.  Model validation involved elasticity tests, value-of-time analysis, and comparison of observed and predicted tour length distributions.  Model specifications were refined iteratively based on model fit, elasticity values, and validation results.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The primary data source is the Household Travel Survey (HTS) data from New South Wales, spanning multiple years (1999-2008).  Specific samples were used for different models, often based on adult status groups and travel purposes.  Data exclusion criteria varied by model and included considerations such as weekday-only data, full-response households, and consistent data.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved re-estimating existing models with updated HTS data and refining model specifications through iterative testing and evaluation of parameter significance.  The approach involved comparing initial estimations using existing model structures with subsequent estimations incorporating new variables and adjustments to improve model fit and address issues such as negative acquisition rates or implausible parameter signs.  The final models were selected based on statistical significance and the plausibility of the estimated parameters.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 2,568 California adults (18+) at baseline; 1,285 completed both waves.  Weights were used to make the sample representative of the California adult population.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Regression analysis was used to assess the change in confidence to intervene among those newly exposed to the campaign, controlling for baseline confidence levels.  The analysis focused on those who reported no exposure at baseline.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Ten trial sites in England implementing the National Model for Liaison and Diversion (L&D), with a focus on four sites for quantitative before-and-after comparisons and economic analysis.  Data included adults and young people, but the economic analysis focused on adults.  Service user feedback was limited (18 participants).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative thematic analysis for interviews and open-ended survey responses.  Quantitative analysis included regression models (fixed-effects multilevel models) to account for site-level clustering and time-constant differences, chi-squared tests for comparing proportions, and cost-benefit analysis for the economic evaluation.  Bayesian expert elicitation was used to estimate health benefits due to data limitations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study includes three large urban school districts (Hillsborough County Public Schools, Memphis City Schools, and Pittsburgh Public Schools) and four California charter management organizations (CMOs) in the College-Ready Promise (TCRP) coalition.  Data on mathematics and reading performance of students in grades 3-8 from 2006-2007 to 2013-2014 were used.  The sample size varies across sites and years, with Aspire Public Schools having a smaller sample size than the districts.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involves estimating teacher value-added using a common model across sites, then examining the sorting of teachers by value-added between LIM and non-LIM students.  Three relationships are estimated: overall, within-school, and between-school.  The analysis also uses site-provided teacher effectiveness measures (value-added or SGP estimates and composites) and decomposes changes in access over time into components attributable to teacher replacement, improvement, and reassignment.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study sample includes all 12 oil and gas refineries operating in California.  Data were collected from structured interviews with refinery personnel.  Historical data on refinery incidents and worker deaths were analyzed to compare incidents under different regulatory regimes (ISO and NISO refineries).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A break-even analysis framework was used to compare the costs and benefits of the proposed regulations.  The analysis considered costs to industry and society, and benefits to industry (costs avoided and safety improvements) and society (costs avoided and other improvements).  Macroeconomic impacts were assessed using the IMPLAN input-output model.  Statistical analysis was used to determine the significance of differences in incident rates and worker death rates between ISO and NISO refineries.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Publicly available sources and information on Russian military doctrine, publications, and statements by military officials.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis of the methods used by Soviet and Russian military analysts to assess COFM, including identification of strengths and weaknesses of different approaches and comparison with similar U.S. methods.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Nationally representative sample of 2,015 parents of school-age children (ages 5-18) recruited from the Ipsos Knowledge Panel.  The sample was weighted to match the national distribution of demographic characteristics.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics (percentages) were calculated for each survey response.  Subgroup comparisons were made using significance testing (p<0.05) to determine statistically significant differences between subgroups and the overall sample.  Multiple hypothesis testing corrections were not used.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative coding of documents to assess information accessibility and marketing practices. Quantitative analysis of survey data using logistic regression, linear probability models, t-tests, and ordered logistic regression.

sample_processes.sample_description: 19 organizations: a mix of public (federal, state, local) and private sector entities.  Public sector organizations were selected to represent a range of innovation sources and perspectives from military service departments and the DoD's Fourth Estate. sample_processes.sample_description: The report uses data from multiple nationally representative surveys, including the American Community Survey (ACS), the National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NSDUH), and the Current Population Survey (CPS).  Specific years and sample sizes vary by dataset and are detailed within each chapter's methodology section.  Data from 2020 are generally excluded due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics and prevalence estimates are calculated, accounting for the complex survey design of each dataset.  Statistical significance testing is conducted to compare veterans and nonveterans, and in some cases, subgroups within the veteran population.  Methods for significance testing vary by variable type (categorical vs. continuous).
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study used data from the ACS-PUMS, CPS-FSS, and BRFSS from 2016-2020, focusing on parents aged 18-59 with children under 17 living with them full-time.  Active-duty service members were excluded from the ACS data.  Qualitative data came from 11 semi-structured interviews with student veteran single parents.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used to analyze the quantitative data.  Qualitative data were analyzed using thematic analysis with inter-rater reliability checks.  No regression analysis was conducted.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Active-component Army soldiers who responded to the 2016 and 2018 WGRA and reported being sexually assaulted in the year prior to survey administration.  Sample size of 1022 (776 women and 246 men).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Exploratory descriptive analysis to identify differences in sexual assault experiences across various subgroups (year, gender, sexual orientation, installation risk level).  Focus on identifying differences of practical importance for policymaking.

sample_processes.sample_description: Three large-scale research projects (arthritis, cardiovascular disease and stroke, mental health) with a total of 63 case studies of separate research projects, ideas, or programs. Case studies included a mix of low, mid, and high impact research, selected using various methods (citation analysis, PI surveys, etc.) depending on the study.  The research projects themselves were conducted 10-20 years prior to the analysis.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The impact of each research project was rated in five categories of the Payback Framework.  Researchers then analyzed what characteristics of the research, researchers, and research environment were associated with high impact in each category.  Findings were compared across the three studies, accounting for methodological differences.  The analysis involved both grouping of findings (e.g., academic vs. wider impact) and separate analysis by impact category.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 18 forward-tracing case studies based on highly cited papers from 1985-1990, stratified by country (Canada, UK, USA) and research type (basic, clinical, interventional). 6 backward-tracing perspectives focusing on specific interventions in schizophrenia treatment.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: For forward-tracing, a nine-member international panel numerically rated the impact of each case study across five payback categories.  Attributes were identified and analyzed to determine associations with high and low impact using the Fisher Exact Test. For backward-tracing, a narrative approach was used to extract and describe attributes that promoted or hindered translation.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

The online focus group included 10 DFID staff. In-depth interviews were conducted with SIEF staff, NGOs, peers (e.g., 3ie, DIME), and donors (CIFF).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Data from different methods were synthesized to answer six core research questions and several secondary research questions.  Analysis included comparing SIEF costs with those of peer funders, examining survey response rates and disaggregating data by respondent characteristics (position, cluster, call for proposal), and assessing workshop data through pre- and post-tests and overall assessments. Qualitative data from interviews and focus groups were also analyzed.

sample_processes.sample_description: Longitudinal data on officers from the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC), covering cohorts entering between 1971 and 2005, with career progression tracked from 2000 to 2010.  Data supplemented with DMDC Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System Point-in-Time Extract (DEERS PITE) for family-related factors.  Officers in professional occupations excluded.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A regression decomposition methodology, based on the Blinder-Oaxaca method, was used to decompose gender differences in career progression.  The analysis considered ten career milestones, each conditional on the preceding outcome.  Linear probability models were estimated using ordinary least squares with heteroscedasticity-robust standard errors.  The results were interpreted cautiously due to potential self-selection bias and endogeneity.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved calculating various metrics annually and presenting them in dashboards.  The methods for calculating each metric are described in detail in the appendix.  The analysis also involved comparing trends over time and across different sites, accounting for changes in data collection procedures and testing regimes.  Statistical tests (e.g., t-tests) were used to compare averages across subgroups.  The analysis also addressed issues of missing data and data standardization across different sites.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from Delaware, Connecticut, and Washington.  The Delaware sample includes student-level administrative data (demographics, enrollment, SBAC scores), school-level achievement data, and LEA-level expenditure data. sample_processes.analysis_approach: Two main comparisons are conducted. Comparison 2 uses regression analysis to examine the association between school expenditures and student achievement, controlling for student and school characteristics. An auxiliary analysis uses quantile regression to investigate achievement gaps across different points of the test score distribution.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Needs were ranked based on expected benefit and probability of success (technical and operational feasibility). sample_processes.sample_description: The study included data from 12 of California's Public Health Care Systems (PHCSs) participating in the Global Payment Program (GPP). Changes were assessed between specific fiscal years (SFY 2015-2016 and SFY 2017-2018 for utilization; SFY 2014-2015 and SFY 2016-2017 for payments and costs). Qualitative data from interviews and surveys were analyzed using inductive and deductive coding approaches to identify themes and variations across PHCSs.

sample_processes.sample_description: School-level data from Florida, Pennsylvania, and Tennessee.  The treatment group consists of schools in Hillsborough County Public Schools (HCPS), Memphis City Schools (MCS), and Pittsburgh Public Schools (PPS). The comparison group includes the remaining schools in each respective state. Charter schools are excluded from the treatment group.  Data from the 2006-2007 to 2008-2009 school years are used as pre-intervention data.  Some adjustments are made to account for the merger of MCS with Shelby County Schools and the transfer of some MCS schools to the Achievement School District.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A two-step process is used for the DiD analysis.  First, a linear regression model is fit to pre-intervention data to predict post-intervention outcomes. Second, a regression is run on the differences between actual and predicted outcomes to estimate the treatment effect.  The SCG method involves constructing a weighted average of comparison districts that closely resembles the intervention district in pre-intervention characteristics.  Statistical inference for the DiD method uses a random-effect model to account for within-district correlation.  The SCG method uses permutation tests (placebo effects) for inference.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Six large urban school districts in the US,  with data from at least SY 2010-2011 through SY 2016-2017.  Comparison schools were selected from non-PPI districts in the same state as the PPI districts, matched on various characteristics.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Quasi-experimental design using DID regression with multivariate matching to estimate causal effects.  Subgroup analyses and exploratory analyses were also conducted.  Academic ROI was calculated using cost data from a separate study.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study used descriptive statistics to analyze qualification rates and continuation rates. Comparative analysis was used to compare the qualification rates of 17C with other MOSs and to compare military pay with civilian wages in relevant occupations.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: For the academic survey, data analysis involved descriptive statistics, cross-question analysis to examine relationships between variables, and chi-squared tests for statistical significance testing. sample_processes.sample_description: Data were collected from three Marine Expeditionary Forces (MEFs): I MEF (Camp Pendleton), II MEF (Camp Lejeune), and III MEF (Camp Butler). sample_processes.analysis_approach: A bottom-up task-frequency-duration model was used to estimate workload. Correlation analysis was used to examine the relationship between demand and the number of supported units.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study sample includes all 12 oil and gas refineries operating in California.  Data were collected from structured interviews with refinery personnel.  Historical data on refinery incidents and worker deaths were analyzed to compare incidents under different regulatory regimes (ISO and NISO refineries).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A break-even analysis framework was used to compare the costs and benefits of the proposed regulations.  The analysis considered costs to industry and society, and benefits to industry (costs avoided and safety improvements) and society (costs avoided and other improvements).  Macroeconomic impacts were assessed using the IMPLAN input-output model.  Statistical analysis was used to determine the significance of differences in incident rates and worker death rates between ISO and NISO refineries.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Difference-in-difference Poisson regression models were used to estimate the effect of SDSC implementation on crime rates, controlling for year, month, and district-specific effects. Bootstrapped standard errors addressed serial correlation in the crime data.  Analysis was conducted using R statistical software.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study focused on a convenience sample of students in a single New York City high school.  The sample included two classrooms of 39 high school seniors in the web design subtrack who took the Startup Tech course.  Comparison students were drawn from the same school, considering students in grades 10-12.  Due to limitations, two model specifications were used: one including students across grades 10-12 with controls for grade and subtrack fixed effects, and another limited to 12th-grade students with controls for admissions track fixed effects.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Two main analytical approaches were employed: 1) Cross-sectional analysis comparing spring 2016 survey responses of Startup Tech students with those of comparison students, adjusting for observable differences using doubly robust estimation and propensity score weighting.  Two model specifications were used here, one with subtrack controls and one with admissions track controls. 2) Difference-in-differences analysis examining changes in individual student survey responses between two survey waves (January and April 2016), comparing changes among Startup Tech students to changes among non-participants.  Again, two model specifications were used, one with subtrack and grade-level controls and one with admissions track controls.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from multiple sources, including a nationally representative survey of high school principals, JROTC textbooks, and data from the American Community Survey (ACS) and the Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC). sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involves descriptive statistics, thematic analysis of qualitative data, and regression modeling with propensity score weighting to account for non-random program placement.  Meta-analysis is used to combine estimates across different urbanicity categories.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study used a sample of 77 simulated coastal storms (eastern half of set 11 from the CLARA Model Improvement Plan report) for the analysis.  These storms varied in central pressure (900 to 960 millibars) and storm size (radius of maximum winds).  The study area included portions of coastal Louisiana and Hancock, Harrison, and Jackson counties in Mississippi.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The CLARA 2.0 model was used to estimate storm surge and wave heights, flood depths, and direct economic damage at various annual exceedance probabilities (AEPs) (10, 50, 100, and 500-year).  The analysis compared a future without action (FWOA) scenario with five proposed barrier configurations.  Parametric uncertainty was incorporated to provide a range of damage and damage reduction estimates.  Results were aggregated by parish or county to assess regional impacts.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data were collected from three Marine Expeditionary Forces (MEFs): I MEF (Camp Pendleton), II MEF (Camp Lejeune), and III MEF (Camp Butler).  The study focused primarily on the Supply Management Units (SMUs) and Repairable Issue Points (RIPs) within each MEF, with additional visits to maintenance and customer units.  Data on task times and frequencies were primarily from III MEF, with SME input used to supplement missing data.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A bottom-up task-frequency-duration model was used to estimate workload.  A Monte Carlo simulation was used to assess the impact of variability in task times and personnel availability.  Correlation analysis was used to examine the relationship between demand and the number of supported units.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

For Domain 2, the study population includes individuals newly covered by the 12-month continuous eligibility policy (treatment group) and a comparison group of children.  A simple random sample of Medicaid enrollees was used for some Domain 2 analyses.  Specific sample sizes are provided throughout the report.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis approach varies by domain and goal but generally involves descriptive statistics, trend analysis, and multivariable regression modeling to assess the impact of the interventions.  Difference-in-differences and survival analysis techniques are used to estimate causal effects.  Huber-White standard errors are used to account for potential heteroskedasticity and intra-person correlation.

sample_processes.sample_description: The academic survey sample was stratified by geographic region, research income, and institution size to include HEIs, PSREs, and RIs, aiming for a mix of UK and non-UK nationals and diverse mobility experiences. The industry survey sample was stratified by size and R&D intensity, targeting R&D-intensive organizations.  Appendix B details the sample characteristics and compares them to national data, revealing over-representation of certain groups (e.g., life sciences researchers, women, EU nationals, white ethnicity) and under-representation of others (e.g., social sciences researchers, men, UK nationals, black and Asian ethnicities).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: For the academic survey, data analysis was performed using R.  Methods included descriptive statistics, cross-question analysis (exploring relationships between variables), and chi-squared tests (for statistical significance testing).  Qualitative analysis was also used to interpret open-ended responses. The industry survey data was not formally analyzed due to low response rates.

sample_processes.sample_description: 299 stakeholders responded to the survey. Over half (153/299) answered in their capacity as a ‘professional representative’ of their organisation and 146 in their capacity as a ‘private individual’.  The respondents represented a wide range of fields, including public health, social care, primary care, cancer, genomics, mental health, geriatrics, child health, patient advocacy, and health policy.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A grounded theory approach was used to identify emergent themes. Three researchers coded the responses in Microsoft Excel, iteratively adding themes. sample_processes.analysis_approach: Data were analyzed using R version 3.5.0.  Quantitative analysis included descriptive statistics and subgroup analyses to compare responses across different groups (career stage, nationality, region, research sector, mobility experience). Qualitative analysis involved thematic coding of free-text responses to identify emerging themes and issues not captured by the structured questions.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study included 115 early childhood programs serving children from the prenatal period to age 5.  The programs encompassed various approaches (ECE, home visiting, parent education, transfers, and combinations).  A total of 3,183 child outcomes were measured across 269 publications and 312 individual abstractions. For effect size calculations, data from 95 outcomes were identified, with 85 having sufficient data to calculate effect sizes.  25 of the 115 programs had formal economic evaluations.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Meta-analysis and meta-regression were used to synthesize the evidence for program impacts.  A random-effects model was employed in the Comprehensive Meta-Analysis (CMA) software to calculate pooled effect sizes.  Economic evaluations included cost analyses, CEAs, and BCAs, with the societal perspective generally adopted for BCAs.  Sensitivity analyses were conducted to assess the robustness of estimates to various assumptions.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 39 articles published between 2000 and 2023 that measured upcoding in provider settings.  The articles were drawn from seven electronic databases and supplemental searches of US government reports.  The majority of studies focused on inpatient hospital admissions, with fewer examining outpatient or office-based settings.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The studies were categorized into five methodological approaches: variations in payments, variations in provider and patient attributes, prediction algorithms, self-reports, and validations.  Each category was analyzed for its strengths and limitations.  The analysis also considered whether studies measured upcoding at the aggregate level or for individual admissions/visits.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study used a RAND database of cost and schedule information from Selected Acquisition Reports (SARs) for major defense acquisition programs (MDAPs) over 40+ years.  Canceled programs were excluded.  The analysis focused on two schedule durations and several program characteristics.  The sample size varied depending on the specific regression (e.g., 94 MDAPs for one regression, 116 for another).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Heterogeneous variance models were used to relate program characteristics at Milestone B to the natural logarithm of schedule durations. Maximum likelihood estimation techniques were employed.  Model refinement involved examining regression statistics and residuals, and addressing potential collinearity.  The models were used to generate schedule point estimates (median and mean) and s-curves representing the distribution of expected schedule outcomes.  These s-curves were then used to benchmark the schedules of five Air Force MDAPs.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Actual state-level, annual firearm death rates from 1979 to 2014 (excluding the District of Columbia), along with state-specific demographic and economic covariates.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study used simulations to assess the performance of various statistical models in estimating the effect of state laws on firearm death rates.  Model performance was evaluated based on four criteria: type 1 error rate, correct rejection rate, directional bias, and magnitude bias.  The simulations varied the true effect of the law, the number of states implementing the law, and the phase-in period of the law's effect.  A wide range of statistical models and standard error adjustment methods were examined.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study used historical Army Combat Fitness Test (ACFT) data and data from a large-scale Army Practice Phase.  The Practice Phase sample aimed to represent various subgroups (gender, age, MOS, component), though some subgroups were underrepresented due to operational constraints.  A workshop included 38 soldiers representing various subgroups.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis included descriptive statistics, regression analysis (linear and logistic), and the development of predictive models to estimate future ACFT performance.  Confidence intervals were calculated to quantify uncertainty in pass rate estimates.  Qualitative data from the soldier workshop were also analyzed.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Quantitative analyses involved descriptive statistics, chi-square tests of association, McNemar's test of paired proportions, and comparisons to existing benchmarks from clinical trials. Qualitative data were analyzed thematically.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study included 31,781 youth who received JJCPA services in FY 2011-2012.  Comparison groups varied by program, including contemporaneous groups (matched on various characteristics), historical comparison groups (previous year's participants), and pre/post comparisons within the same youth.  Sample sizes varied across programs and outcome measures.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Statistical significance assessed using chi-square tests and difference-of-means tests, with p<0.05 indicating significance.  Difference-in-differences analyses used logistic regression to control for baseline differences between cohorts when comparing current and previous years' data.  Mean and median costs were calculated and compared for cost analyses.
