sample_processes.sample_description: Nondeployed active-duty service members who received a new mTBI diagnosis in calendar year 2012, excluding National Guard and Reserve members.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive analyses were conducted to characterize the sample and their care. Relative risk analysis was used to identify risk factors for persistent care needs.  T-tests and chi-square tests were used to compare groups. Multivariate regression was used to adjust for confounding variables.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Two probability-based samples of California adults, with oversampling of Spanish-speaking and rural residents.  A subset of participants (n=538) participated in both surveys. Sample size of 1,284 at baseline and 1,583 at follow-up (after removing 5 incomplete responses). Sample weighted to be representative of the California adult population.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, chi-square tests to compare distributions of outcomes across demographic groups, logistic regressions to predict outcomes based on demographic variables and campaign exposure. Longitudinal analyses (N=538) were conducted to assess changes in outcomes over time, controlling for baseline values and demographics.

Specific case studies are detailed throughout the document.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative and quantitative analysis methods are used.  Qualitative analysis involves reviewing and interpreting case studies and interview notes to identify common themes and promising practices. Quantitative analysis includes statistical methods such as regression, clustering, classification, and spatiotemporal modeling.  The analysis also involves developing a taxonomy to organize and categorize the various predictive policing methods and interventions.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Weighted means were calculated using a main weight to ensure national representativeness. sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from New York City Department of Education (NYCDOE) schools.  Community schools are compared to a matched comparison group of similar schools that were not designated as community schools. Subgroup analyses are conducted for various student and school characteristics.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A difference-in-differences approach is used to estimate the impact of the NYC Community Schools Initiative (NYC-CS).  School-level average outcomes are used in the primary analysis.  Weighted least squares regression is employed, with standard errors clustered by school.  Subgroup analyses are conducted to examine heterogeneity in program impacts based on student and school characteristics.  A grade-by-year analysis decomposes changes in impact over time into maturity and exposure components.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study examined 14 weapon systems, with a focused analysis on small arms (M16/M4 rifle, M249 SAW, M240B machine gun).  Data from other nations' armies and the USMC were also used for comparison.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative analysis was the primary approach, with quantitative data used to support comparisons and inform the development of research designs.  The study used a comparative approach to examine the Army's small arms training strategies against those of other nations and the USMC.  For the efficiency analysis, the study proposed quasi-experimental designs to test the impact of different training strategies on soldier proficiency.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study population included all 2015 and 2016 beneficiary-months where the beneficiary was enrolled in Medicare Part A or B, enrolled in an MA contract, and whose reason for entitlement was not ESRD.  Beneficiary-months for MSA, cost, PACE, and MMP plans were excluded.  The final sample included local and regional coordinated care plans (CCPs) and private fee-for-service (PFFS) plans.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved calculating monthly and yearly utilization measures for five main categories (inpatient hospital stays, outpatient hospital visits, emergency department visits, other outpatient facility visits, and professional visits) and additional line-level measures.  Descriptive statistics (means, standard deviations, and proportions) were calculated for each measure, separately for 2015 and 2016, and for different plan types.  Test statistics were used to assess statistically significant changes in means between 2015 and 2016 at the beneficiary-month level.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data from IQVIA MIDAS database covering 2017-2022 for the United States and 33 other OECD countries.  Animal insulins and inhaled insulins were excluded.  The analysis is limited to insulins sold in the United States, with comparisons made to matching products in other countries.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Price index-based comparisons holding the mix of insulins constant between the United States and comparison countries.  Comparisons were made for all insulins combined and for different categories of insulins.  Analyses were conducted using both gross prices and estimated net prices (after applying a 76% discount to US gross prices).  Both standard units (SUs) and international units (IUs) were used for volume measurement, and results were compared.  Robustness checks were performed by aggregating data at the active ingredient level.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study involved data from seven initial sites (three school districts and four charter management organizations) and an eighth site added later.  Data included administrative data, teacher and school leader surveys, classroom observations, and student and parent satisfaction surveys.  The data covered a 12-year period (SY 2006–2007 to SY 2017–2018).  Specific subgroups of students (e.g., low-income minority students) were analyzed.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved calculating various metrics annually and presenting them in dashboards.  The methods for calculating each metric are described in detail in the appendix.  The analysis also involved comparing trends over time and across different sites, accounting for changes in data collection procedures and testing regimes.  Statistical tests (e.g., t-tests) were used to compare averages across subgroups.  The analysis also addressed issues of missing data and data standardization across different sites.

sample_processes.sample_description: 71 insurgencies begun and completed worldwide between World War II and 2010.  A core set of 59 cases was used for most analyses after excluding cases fought against the tide of history and one case with an indeterminate outcome. Subpopulations were also analyzed: iron fist, motive-focused, and external actor cases.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study employed a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative case narratives with quantitative analysis.  Bivariate analysis examined relationships between individual factors and outcomes. QCA identified minimally sufficient configurations of factors explaining success and failure. sample_processes.analysis_approach: Pre- and post-test scores were compared using t-tests for mean estimates and chi-square tests for percentage estimates.  A p-value less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

T-tests and chi-square tests were used to compare groups. Multivariate regression was used to adjust for confounding variables.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 7,217 K–12 public school teachers from the 2021 American Instructional Resources Survey (AIRS).  The sample included early childhood/general elementary teachers and departmentalized ELA, math, or science teachers.  Social studies teachers were not included, potentially underestimating anti-bias education prevalence, especially at the secondary level.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were used to compare teacher responses across various school and teacher characteristics.  Open-ended responses were analyzed using qualitative methods, including keyword identification and categorization.  T-tests were used to assess statistical significance (p<0.05). Regression models were used to check the robustness of findings by controlling for school and teacher characteristics.  The report presents unadjusted descriptive results.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Nationally representative samples of K–12 teachers (ELA, math, science) and principals; state-representative samples of teachers in IMPD Network states (and California, Florida, New York, Washington).  Focus on ELA and math teachers in this report.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, comparisons of IMPD Network states to national averages using t-tests, multinomial logistic regression to examine relationships between supports, use of standards-aligned materials, and IMPD Network participation/material adoption status.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative data coded using Dedoose software. Over 300 stakeholders were interviewed, including employers, institutional leaders, and departmental experts from universities and community colleges.

The study also involved qualitative analysis of interview data and literature review findings.  The analysis considered indicators of supply and demand for baccalaureate-level workers in the chosen fields and regions.

sample_processes.sample_description: The study included 15 interviews with global experts and government/multilateral officials, analysis of UNHCR data on 53 postconflict return cases, and case studies in three regions (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, and the Kurdistan Region–Iraq) involving focus groups and interviews with 105 returnees, refugees, and IDPs, and interviews with 30 stakeholders.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved examining cross-national trends in displacement and returns over 30 years, developing a new way of measuring returns, and analyzing commonalities and differences across the case studies.

sample_processes.sample_description: A national sample of veteran-serving organizations was recruited through multiple methods, including directories, keyword searches, and professional networks.  The final survey sample included 87 organizations, with a smaller subset (15) participating in follow-up interviews.  The interview sample was purposively selected to ensure variation in organization size, geographic location, and program type.  The study acknowledges limitations in generalizability due to non-random sampling.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative data from interviews were analyzed using QSR NVivo software with a structural coding approach to identify major themes.  Quantitative data from the survey were also analyzed, including descriptive statistics and comparisons between different program types. The study notes that the findings from the interviews are not necessarily generalizable to the full population of veteran-serving organizations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Quantitative data were analyzed using statistical tests (e.g., significance testing, correlation). Qualitative data were analyzed using Atlas.ti software and a grounded theory approach.  An intent-to-treat approach was used for some analyses to account for missing data.

sample_processes.sample_description: 384 individuals enrolled in Project imPACT between June 2020 and September 2022.  The sample included significant regional differences in age, gender, and race/ethnicity, reflecting the broader demographics of the Los Angeles areas served. Most Fellows were unemployed at enrollment and many were staying with family or friends.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Thematic analysis of interview transcripts using Atlas.ti software and a grounded theory approach. sample_processes.sample_description: The study sample consisted of adult patients (18 years and older) who received ambulatory palliative care visits.  The sample was drawn from 44 palliative care programs across the United States, with an oversampling of larger programs and stratification by administrative home type and geographic location. A mixed-mode survey was administered to approximately 7,595 patients, resulting in 2,804 completed surveys used for analysis.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved multiple statistical techniques, including hierarchical generalized linear models to account for the hierarchical structure of the data (patients nested within programs), Bayesian methods for estimating reliability and ICC, bivariate correlations to assess validity, ANOVA and Fisher's exact tests for risk adjustment analyses, and a ranking approach to interpret the practical significance of program-level differences.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: A nationally representative sample of 44 ambulatory palliative care programs across the United States.  The final analytic sample consisted of 2,804 completed patient surveys.  The sample was predominantly female, White, non-Hispanic/Latino, and highly educated.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Data element and measure-level reliability and validity were assessed.  Hierarchical generalized linear models were used to estimate risk-adjusted program-level measure scores and assess reliability.  Bivariate correlations were used to assess convergent validity.  Qualitative data from program and patient interviews were analyzed using thematic analysis.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved identifying and visualizing relationships between vulnerability severity and exploitability, examining software dependencies and ownership structures, estimating economic loss and interconnectedness using a firm-level input/output model, and mapping NCFs to software companies through a software taxonomy.

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Analysis of claims data to identify index procedures, categorize services, and calculate utilization and payments for services within a nine-day episode around each index procedure.  Analysis of practice and patient characteristics to inform eligibility criteria.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data from all U.S. states except Maryland, including claims from self-insured employers, state APCDs (11 states), and several state employee plans.  The data include hospital inpatient, outpatient, and non-hospital services from 2018-2020.  The sample includes approximately 1.3 million inpatient hospital stays, 12.2 million hospital outpatient services, and 798,000 ASC procedures.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The primary analysis involves calculating standardized and relative prices. Standardized prices are calculated by dividing the total allowed amount for a basket of services by the number of standardized units of service. Relative prices are calculated as the ratio of the allowed amount from private health plan claims to the Medicare allowed amount for the same services at the same hospital.  Regression analysis is used to examine the correlation between hospital market share and prices, and the relationship between hospital prices and the share of non-private insurance discharges.  The study also analyzes the relationship between hospital prices and quality metrics (CMS star ratings and Leapfrog Hospital Safety Grades).
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study used data from all U.S. states except Maryland, including claims data from self-insured employers, state all-payer claims databases (APCDs), and state employee plans.  The data covered hospital and other provider spending from 2020 to 2022. The sample included over 4,000 hospitals and over 4,000 ASCs.  The analysis included approximately 1.3 million inpatient hospital stays, 11.2 million hospital outpatient services, and 1.2 million ASC procedures.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis focused on calculating and comparing two types of prices: standardized prices (average allowed amount per standardized unit of service) and relative prices (actual private insurer allowed amount divided by the Medicare allowed amount for the same services at the same hospital).  Medicare's pricing algorithms were used to simulate Medicare payments.  Regression analysis was used to examine the relationship between hospital prices and factors such as quality, patient composition, and market share.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Medicare fee-for-service claims data for procedures furnished during calendar year 2019 in nine states with mandatory reporting of post-operative visits (Florida, Kentucky, Louisiana, Nevada, New Jersey, North Dakota, Ohio, Oregon, and Rhode Island).  The sample included practitioners in practices with ten or more practitioners.  Sub-analyses focused on specific subsets of practitioners (e.g., robust reporters, high-volume practitioners).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The primary analysis focused on calculating the share of procedures with any reported post-operative visits and the ratio of observed to expected post-operative visits.  Numerous sensitivity analyses were conducted to address potential biases and confounding factors, including variations in the definition of clean procedures, inclusion/exclusion of specific practitioner groups, and expansion of the definition of post-operative care to include E&M visits and other procedures.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The 2022 AIRS used the RAND American Educator Panels (AEP), which includes nationally representative samples of K-12 public school educators and leaders.  The teacher sample aimed for 7900 completed surveys, with 400 completed surveys in each of 16 oversampled states and 1500 across the remaining states. The principal sample aimed for 1500 completed surveys nationally.  Oversampled states included those participating in the CCSSO IMPD Network and other states of funder interest (California, Florida, New York).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The final analysis weights are a product of three interim weights: calibrated weight of the ATP/ASLP sampling frame, sample selection weight, and survey response weight.  These weights were recalibrated and trimmed to ensure representative sample and limit design effect.  Replicate weights were not produced; variance estimation using the provided single weight was deemed sufficient.

sample_processes.sample_description: The analytic sample consisted of 2,482 active-component Army soldiers (1,582 women and 900 men) with nonzero weights who experienced sexual harassment in the 12 months prior to the 2018 WGRA and completed the online survey version.  Soldiers assigned to the Pentagon or military academies were excluded.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved creating profiles of sexual harassment and gender discrimination experiences based on respondents' most serious incidents.  These profiles included the types of behaviors, perpetrator characteristics, and time and place of the incidents.  Statistical significance was assessed using Rao-Scott chi-squared tests with a p-value cutoff of 0.05.  Clopper-Pearson exact confidence intervals were used to account for uncertainty in the estimates.  Installations with fewer than 30 respondents were grouped to protect privacy.

sample_processes.sample_description: Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries in nine states who received procedures with 10- or 90-day global periods from July 1, 2017 to December 31, 2018.  Sub-samples include only those in practices with 10 or more practitioners, and further sub-samples focus on 'robust reporters' and 'high-volume reporters'.  Analysis is primarily limited to 'clean procedures' (single procedures not overlapping with other procedures with global periods).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The study uses claims data to determine the number of post-operative visits reported using HCPCS code 99024.  This is compared to the expected number of visits from the Physician Time File.  Various sensitivity analyses are conducted to address potential underreporting and alternative definitions of post-operative care.  The primary outcomes are the share of procedures with any post-operative visits and the ratio of observed-to-expected post-operative visits.

The sample included practitioners in practices with ten or more practitioners.  Sub-analyses focused on specific subsets of practitioners (e.g., robust reporters, high-volume practitioners).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The primary analysis focused on calculating the share of procedures with any reported post-operative visits and the ratio of observed to expected post-operative visits.  Numerous sensitivity analyses were conducted to address potential biases and confounding factors, including variations in the definition of clean procedures, inclusion/exclusion of specific practitioner groups, and expansion of the definition of post-operative care to include E&M visits and other procedures.

Visual scribing provided a complementary qualitative analysis, with aggregation and comparison of the resulting images.

sample_processes.sample_description: 412 federal cyberstalking cases (2010-2020); 23 subject-matter experts (prosecutors, investigators, law enforcement, victim advocates, researchers).  Sampling for experts was non-probabilistic convenience and chain sampling.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Quantitative analysis of case data (e.g., frequencies, durations, conviction rates, sentences); Qualitative thematic analysis of interview data.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study uses data on US occupations from O*NET, US patents from the USPTO and AIPD, and wage and employment data from the US Census and ACS.  The sample for wage and employment analysis is restricted to workers aged 18-65.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involves matching patents to occupational tasks using NLP, aggregating data to the occupation level, and using regression analysis to examine the correlations between technology exposure and labor market outcomes (wages and employment growth).
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 103 English-speaking U.S. citizens aged 18–60, associated with the University of New Haven.  The sample was not perfectly balanced between truthful and deceptive conditions.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Multiple machine learning models were trained and tested using various linguistic features extracted from interview transcripts and chat logs.  Model performance was evaluated using accuracy rates and other metrics.  A nested three-fold cross-validation strategy was employed to mitigate overfitting.  Gender bias was assessed by analyzing model performance separately for male and female participants.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study focused on three geographic areas: metro Atlanta, Los Angeles County, and New York City.  The landscape review covered funding sources available from 2018–2023.  Interviews were conducted with nine organizations serving foster TAY, nine foster TAY, and five caregivers.  Interview participants were recruited using convenience sampling.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The landscape review data were abstracted into a spreadsheet and analyzed descriptively.  Qualitative interview data were analyzed using thematic analysis with a codebook to ensure consistency.

sample_processes.sample_description: The sample consisted of 264 RAND reports on ABD/A, dating back to 1951.  A subset of 95 unclassified or declassified reports was used for the detailed historical analysis in Chapters 3-6.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics were generated on report content. Network analysis was performed on author co-authorship data using Python packages.  The historical narrative chapters focused on unclassified/declassified reports.

sample_processes.sample_description: 64 policy papers published between January 2, 2016, and December 11, 2020, focusing on recommendations to address disinformation or propaganda.  The majority were from the US, with some from Europe. Most focused on propaganda and social media.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative coding using Dedoose software to categorize recommendations into major categories (social media platform policies, U.S. and allied government policies, coordination recommendations, awareness and education recommendations, recommendations for supporting various media and media content) and subcategories.  The analysis focused on categorizing and explaining recommendations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 39 articles published between 2000 and 2023 that measured upcoding in provider settings.  The articles were drawn from seven electronic databases and supplemental searches of US government reports.  The majority of studies focused on inpatient hospital admissions, with fewer examining outpatient or office-based settings.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The studies were categorized into five methodological approaches: variations in payments, variations in provider and patient attributes, prediction algorithms, self-reports, and validations.  Each category was analyzed for its strengths and limitations.  The analysis also considered whether studies measured upcoding at the aggregate level or for individual admissions/visits.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: 98 peer-reviewed articles and reports on the Deepwater Horizon oil spill published between 2010 and 2019, sourced from various databases.  The included studies varied in research design, sampling strategy, sample type, and geographic area.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative synthesis of findings across diverse studies, due to the heterogeneity of the literature.  Workshop discussions with subject-matter experts to elicit feedback and identify recommendations.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study used AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance (GCDF) Dataset version 2.0, which includes data on 13,427 Chinese projects across 145 countries.  The sample was further refined through iterative searches and manual review, resulting in a final dataset of 155 AI-related projects.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved iterative refinement of search terms, manual coding of projects into AI application or AI infrastructure categories, and the addition of contextual information from external sources.  The final dataset was used to create an interactive world map and country selector tool.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data covers the year 2018 and spans 33 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, including the United States.  Animal insulin products were excluded.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: A price index approach was used, comparing US prices to those of other countries, holding a constant market basket at US volume shares by presentation.  Comparisons were made for all insulins and for specific type and timing categories.  Price ratios were reported. A sensitivity analysis was conducted using data aggregated at the active-ingredient level instead of the presentation level.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.analysis_approach: The quantitative analysis uses descriptive statistics and chi-square tests. The qualitative analysis uses axial coding to identify themes from interview transcripts and sentiment analysis of social media data.

Social workers, behavioral health technicians, and congressional policymakers were not included.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis was largely descriptive and interpretive, drawing inferences from the interviews and timeline of events. sample_processes.sample_description: The study used historical Army Combat Fitness Test (ACFT) data and data from a large-scale Army Practice Phase.  The Practice Phase sample aimed to represent various subgroups (gender, age, MOS, component), though some subgroups were underrepresented due to operational constraints.  A workshop included 38 soldiers representing various subgroups.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis included descriptive statistics, regression analysis (linear and logistic), and the development of predictive models to estimate future ACFT performance.  Confidence intervals were calculated to quantify uncertainty in pass rate estimates.  Qualitative data from the soldier workshop were also analyzed.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study focused on the Weinberg Center for Elder Justice in NYC and its Elder Abuse Shelter (EAS) model.  Data also included information from six SPRiNG Alliance member organizations and various stakeholders (APS, hospitals, law enforcement, etc.).  Sample sizes for proposed evaluation designs varied, with recommendations of at least 100 participants in each arm for some designs, and a total of 200 participants for others.  The actual number of Weinberg Center clients was relatively small (16-34 per year).
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Qualitative data analysis involved manual coding and thematic analysis using Dedoose software.  Quantitative analysis for the proposed evaluation designs would involve various statistical methods depending on the chosen design (e.g., comparison of means, regression analysis, propensity score matching).
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: The study sample consisted of adult patients (18 years and older) who received ambulatory palliative care visits.  The sample was drawn from 44 palliative care programs across the United States, with an oversampling of larger programs and stratification by administrative home type and geographic location. A mixed-mode survey was administered to approximately 7,595 patients, resulting in 2,804 completed surveys used for analysis.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: The analysis involved multiple statistical techniques, including hierarchical generalized linear models to account for the hierarchical structure of the data (patients nested within programs), Bayesian methods for estimating reliability and ICC, bivariate correlations to assess validity, ANOVA and Fisher's exact tests for risk adjustment analyses, and a ranking approach to interpret the practical significance of program-level differences.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: A nationally representative sample of 44 ambulatory palliative care programs across the United States.  The final analytic sample consisted of 2,804 completed patient surveys.  The sample was predominantly female, White, non-Hispanic/Latino, and highly educated.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Data element and measure-level reliability and validity were assessed.  Hierarchical generalized linear models were used to estimate risk-adjusted program-level measure scores and assess reliability.  Bivariate correlations were used to assess convergent validity.  Qualitative data from program and patient interviews were analyzed using thematic analysis.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data from IQVIA MIDAS database covering 2017-2022 for the United States and 33 other OECD countries.  Animal insulins and inhaled insulins were excluded.  The analysis is limited to insulins sold in the United States, with comparisons made to matching products in other countries.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Price index-based comparisons holding the mix of insulins constant between the United States and comparison countries.  Comparisons were made for all insulins combined and for different categories of insulins.  Analyses were conducted using both gross prices and estimated net prices (after applying a 76% discount to US gross prices).  Both standard units (SUs) and international units (IUs) were used for volume measurement, and results were compared.  Robustness checks were performed by aggregating data at the active ingredient level.
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.sample_description: Data from IQVIA MIDAS for 2022, covering the United States and 33 other OECD countries.  Data were cleaned to exclude over-the-counter drugs, records with non-positive volume or sales, inconsistent data, and presentations with low volume or sales.  The final sample varied depending on the specific analysis.
sample_processes.analysis_approach: Bilateral price index comparisons were conducted between the U.S. and each of the other 33 countries, as well as a comparison of U.S. prices with the average of all other countries.  U.S. volume weights were primarily used, with sensitivity analyses using other country weights and blended weights.  Subgroup analyses were performed for different drug categories, and sensitivity analyses explored the impact of various methodological choices (e.g., aggregation level, price ratio exclusion criteria).
sample_processes.data_source: LLM analysis of full document methodology sections

sample_processes.analysis_approach: Descriptive statistics, bivariate analyses, significance tests (p<0.05), odds ratios, sample weighting to ensure demographic representativeness.
